auto_merge.commit_message:
Cython currently creates very big .so files which is problematic especially for packages containing many Cython compiled modules. We now allow users to generate a shared library containing (for now: only) the MemoryView utility code which is loaded via the standard cimport mechanism by all other modules that know about it.

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2356
See https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6042
See https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/27767
auto_merge.commit_title: Generate and use shared library for MemoryView Utility code (GH-6728)

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is variant of #6531 with `shared_utility_qualified_name` as `Context` attribute:

```python
######## setup.py ########

from Cython.Build import cythonize
from Cython.Compiler import Options
from setuptools import setup, Extension
import numpy

extensions = [
    Extension("*", ["**/*.pyx"], include_dirs=[numpy.get_include()]),
    Extension("pkg2.CythonShared", sources=["pkg2/CythonShared.c"])
]

setup(
  ext_modules = cythonize(extensions, shared_utility_qualified_name = 'pkg2.CythonShared')
)
```

> [!NOTE] 
> ~There is missing peace of code for including shared library as dependency.~ Moreover, we should define how we will proceed with #6691 (we are introducing the parameter but the logic for creation of package is not present)

comment_data.body: I still think that we should have one option that defines the qualified shared module name, and then write it into the working directory (given by `--working`). I don't think we need users to specify a C file path. That just seems redundant.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -158,6 +157,11 @@ def create_cython_argparser():
                            'deduced from the import path if source file is in '
                            'a package, or equals the filename otherwise.')
     parser.add_argument('-M', '--depfile', action='store_true', help='produce depfiles for the sources')
+    parser.add_argument("--generate-shared", dest='shared_c_file_path', action='store', type=str,
+                        help='Generates shared module with specified name.')
+    parser.add_argument("--shared", dest='shared_utility_qualified_name', action='store', type=str,
+                        help='Imports utility code from shared module specified by fully qualified module name.')

comment_data.body: Not a directive any more.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1050,6 +1118,11 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     cause Cython 3.0 to have the same semantics as Cython 0.x. This directive was solely added
     to help migrate legacy code written before Cython 3. It will be removed in a future release.
 
+``shared_utility_qualified_name`` (fully qualified module name), *default=""*
+    When set, cython will automatically cimport and use internal utility code from the provided
+    shared module instead of embedding it. This can yield a smaller package size because
+    the shared utility code is present only in shared module. See :ref:`shared_module` for more detail.

comment_data.body:
~I just noticed that this doesn't work. Passing the `context` dict misfits the `@cached_function`. Actually, even using it seems already wrong. I'd remove the decorator.~

The isn't true as long as we're not passing the `context` dict as an actual argument, which we don't. So my change is actually fine.

comment_data.body: The difference between `self._context` and `cython_scope.context` is everything but clear.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -265,6 +271,68 @@ def filter_inherited_directives(current_directives):
         return utility_code_directives
 
 
+class TemplatedFileSourceDescriptor(FileSourceDescriptor):
+
+    def __init__(self, filename, path_description, context):
+        super().__init__(filename, path_description)
+        self._context = context
+
+    def get_file_object(self, encoding=None, error_handling=None):
+        with super().get_file_object(encoding, error_handling) as f:
+            data = f.read()
+            ret = Code.sub_tempita(data, self._context, self.filename)
+            stream = io.TextIOWrapper(io.BytesIO(ret.encode(f.encoding)), encoding=f.encoding, errors=error_handling)
+        return stream
+
+
+class CythonSharedUtilityCode(Code.AbstractUtilityCode):
+    def __init__(self, shared_utility_qualified_name, context, requires):
+        self._shared_utility_qualified_name = shared_utility_qualified_name
+        self.context = context
+        self.requires = requires
+        self._shared_library_scope = None
+
+    def find_module(self, context):
+        scope = context
+        for name, is_package in scope._split_qualified_name(self._shared_utility_qualified_name, relative_import=False):
+            scope = scope.find_submodule(name, as_package=is_package)
+
+        pxd_pathname = os.path.join(
+            os.path.split(Cython.__file__)[0],
+            'Utility',
+            'MemoryView.pxd'
+        )
+        try:
+            rel_path = self._shared_utility_qualified_name.replace('.', os.sep) + os.path.splitext(pxd_pathname)[1]
+            source_desc = TemplatedFileSourceDescriptor(pxd_pathname, rel_path, self.context)
+            source_desc.in_utility_code = True
+            err, result = context.process_pxd(source_desc, scope, self._shared_utility_qualified_name)
+            (pxd_codenodes, pxd_scope) = result
+            context.utility_pxd = (pxd_codenodes, pxd_scope)
+            scope.pxd_file_loaded = True
+            if err:
+                raise err
+        except CompileError:
+            pass
+        return scope
+
+    def declare_in_scope(self, dest_scope, used=False, cython_scope=None,
+                         allowlist=None):
+        if not cython_scope.context.utility_pxd:
+            self._shared_library_scope = self.find_module(cython_scope.context)

comment_data.body: Yes I agree it's a mess. We have `Cython.Compiler.Main.Context` class and dictionary with templating context both stored in variables with name `context`. I propose to rename variables `context` having templating dictionary as `template_context`. I think it will greatly improve readability.

comment_data.body:
Unfortunately not. Downstream code expects `encoding` attribute which `StringIO` does not set:

```python
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Compiler/Parsing.py", line 810, in p_atom_string
    kind, bytes_value, unicode_value = p_cat_string_literal(s)
                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

    kind, bytes_value, unicode_value = p_string_literal(s)
                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Compiler/Parsing.py", line 1066, in p_string_literal
    chars.append(systr)
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Compiler/StringEncoding.py", line 85, in append
    self._bytes.append(characters)
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Compiler/StringEncoding.py", line 55, in append
    characters = characters.encode(self.target_encoding)
                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
TypeError: encode() argument 'encoding' must be str, not None
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/dev/cython/TEST_TMP/memoryview/memoryview_shared_utility/setup.py", line 13, in <module>
    ext_modules = cythonize(extensions, shared_utility_qualified_name = 'pkg2.CythonShared')
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1112, in cythonize
    cythonize_one(*args)
  File "/root/dev/cython/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1255, in cythonize_one
    raise CompileError(None, pyx_file)
Cython.Compiler.Errors.CompileError: pkg1/pkg11/add_one.pyx
[-1] ['/root/dev/cython3.11/bin/python', '/root/dev/cython/cython.py', '--generate-shared=pkg2/CythonShared.c']



[-1] ['/root/dev/cython3.11/bin/python', 'setup.py', 'build_ext', '--inplace']
```

I added comment about that fact.

comment_data.body:
OK I created separate method implementing above for. It turned out that it is used only in one place, so I did not create additional `internalise_c_class_entries()`. The name of new method is `merge_scope()` which I don't like because:
* it is too generic
* it is used in other places
but I cannot come with better name any suggestions?

                 entry.type.module_name = self.full_module_name
-                entry.type.scope.directives["internal"] = True
+                entry.type.scope.directives["internal"] = internalise_c_class_entries
 
             self.scope.merge_in(scope)

comment_data.body:
> we should have one option that defines the qualified shared module name, and then write it into the working directory (given by --working)

If I correctly understand you want for following project structure:
```
src/
  pkg2/
      __init__.py
  pkg1/
     __init__.py
     mymodule.pyx
```
```
cd src/pkg2
cython --shared pkg2.CythonShared --working
```

will create new file `CythonShared.c` in `/src/pkg2` directory. And then:

```
cd ..
cython --shared pkg2.CythonShared pkg1/mymodule.pyx
```

But honestly I consider it not intuitive we are missing explicit command instructing cython to generate module (e.g. what will happen if we run `cython --shared pkg2.CythonShared` without `--working`?)

**In general, I don't want to block any decision. If above workflow is what we want I will implement it.**

BTW. small side node. I am longer thinking about rewriting whole cython CLI into subcommands (e.g. like git and other tools):

* `cython compile mymodule.pyx` as replacement for regular `cython mymodule.pyx` (including arguments)
* `cython build mymodule.pyx` as replacement for `cythonize mymodule.pyx` (including arguments
* `cython generate_shared ...` to generate shared module

comment_data.body: Seeing this, it really makes no sense. The `Context` knows its `.options` and we're only duplicating the option into the `Context` here.  Just go through the options then. That will mean that several places that now pass the `Context` down into a function can instead pass only `context.options`. Again, less dependencies.

> rewriting whole cython CLI into subcommands

That would be a major disruption for users. I don't think we can do that.

> I don't think we need users to specify a C file path. That just seems redundant.

I'm fine with keeping the two CLI options.

+    parser.add_argument("--shared", dest='shared_utility_qualified_name', action='store', type=str,
+                        help='Imports utility code from shared module specified by fully qualified module name.')

I hope now it is OK.
This can just receive `options` instead of `context`.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -447,6 +447,74 @@ e.g.::
 These ``.pxd`` files need not have corresponding ``.pyx``
 modules if they contain purely declarations of external libraries.
 
+.. _shared_module:
+
+Shared utility module
+=====================
+
+When a ``.pyx``/``.py`` file is compiled to ``.c`` file, cython automatically embeds utility code to the resulting ``.c`` file. For projects containing multiple cython modules, it
+can result with larger total size of compiled extensions. To avoid redundant code, the shared utility code can be generated to a separate extension module which is
+automatically cimported and used by the user-written extension modules.
+
+.. note:: Currently only memoryview utility code can be generated in the shared utility module.
+
+Consider the following example package ::
+
+    mypkg/
+    +-- __init__.py
+    +-- shared/
+    |   +-- __init__.py
+    |   +-- _cyutility.c
+    +-- subpkg1/
+        +-- __init__.py
+        +-- module.pyx
+
+The :file:`_cyutility.c` file contains shared utility code and :file:`module.pyx` is a standard cython source file which will be compiled into an extension cimporting ``mypkg.shared._cyutility`` module.
+The compilation process now consist of four steps:
+
+1. generating shared utility code. This is done via ``--generate-shared`` argument:
+
+   .. code-block:: console
+
+       $ cython --generate-shared=mypkg/shared/_cyutility.c
+
+2. compiling the shared utility code. The module needs to be compiled as regular ``.c`` file, either by using the
+C compiler directly, or through setuptools, etc.
+3. compiling ``.pyx`` file to ``.c`` file with the ``--shared`` argument to give the name of the shared module:
+
+   .. code-block:: console
+
+        $ cython --shared=mypkg.shared._cyutility module.pyx
+
+4. compiling ``module.c`` file
+
+.. warning:: An extension module compiled with ``--shared=...`` argument, automatically imports the shared module under the fully qualified name provided via the argument parameter. Failing to import the shared module will cause a failure of the extension module import.
+
+Compiling shared module using setuptools
+----------------------------------------
+
+To simplify the compilation process, setuptools can be used. To specify the fully qualified module name of the shared utility, the ``shared_utility_qualified_name`` option can be used instead of the ``--shared`` argument. The :file:`setup.py` file would be:
+
+.. code-block:: python
+    :caption: setup.py
+
+    from Cython.Build import cythonize
+    from Cython.Compiler import Options
+    from setuptools import setup, Extension
+
+    Options.shared_utility_qualified_name = 'mypkg.shared._cyutility'

```suggestion
                MemoryView.get_view_utility_code(options.shared_utility_qualified_name))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+import tempfile
+import os
+import shutil
+
+from Cython.Compiler import (
+    MemoryView, Code, Options, Pipeline, Errors, Main, Symtab
+)
+from Cython.Compiler.StringEncoding import EncodedString
+from Cython.Compiler.Scanning import FileSourceDescriptor
+
+def create_shared_library_pipeline(context, scope, options, result):
+
+    # "cimport_from_pyx=True" to force generating __Pyx_ExportFunction
+    parse = Pipeline.parse_stage_factory(context, cimport_from_pyx=True)
+
+    def generate_tree_factory(context):
+        def generate_tree(compsrc):
+            tree = parse(compsrc)
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(
+                    MemoryView.get_view_utility_code(context.shared_utility_qualified_name))

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -447,6 +447,74 @@ e.g.::
 These ``.pxd`` files need not have corresponding ``.pyx``
 modules if they contain purely declarations of external libraries.
 
+.. _shared_module:
+
+Shared utility module
+=====================
+
+When a ``.pyx``/``.py`` file is compiled to ``.c`` file, cython automatically embeds utility code to the resulting ``.c`` file. For projects containing multiple cython modules, it
+can result with larger total size of compiled extensions. To avoid redundant code, the shared utility code can be generated to a separate extension module which is
+automatically cimported and used by the user-written extension modules.
+
+.. note:: Currently only memoryview utility code can be generated in the shared utility module.
+
+Consider the following example package ::
+
+    mypkg/
+    +-- __init__.py
+    +-- shared/
+    |   +-- __init__.py
+    |   +-- _cyutility.c
+    +-- subpkg1/
+        +-- __init__.py
+        +-- module.pyx
+
+The :file:`_cyutility.c` file contains shared utility code and :file:`module.pyx` is a standard cython source file which will be compiled into an extension cimporting ``mypkg.shared._cyutility`` module.
+The compilation process now consist of four steps:
+
+1. generating shared utility code. This is done via ``--generate-shared`` argument:
+
+   .. code-block:: console
+
+       $ cython --generate-shared=mypkg/shared/_cyutility.c
+
+2. compiling the shared utility code. The module needs to be compiled as regular ``.c`` file, either by using the
+C compiler directly, or through setuptools, etc.
+3. compiling ``.pyx`` file to ``.c`` file with the ``--shared`` argument to give the name of the shared module:
+
+   .. code-block:: console
+
+        $ cython --shared=mypkg.shared._cyutility module.pyx
+
+4. compiling ``module.c`` file
+
+.. warning:: An extension module compiled with ``--shared=...`` argument, automatically imports the shared module under the fully qualified name provided via the argument parameter. Failing to import the shared module will cause a failure of the extension module import.
+
+Compiling shared module using setuptools
+----------------------------------------
+
+To simplify the compilation process, setuptools can be used. To specify the fully qualified module name of the shared utility, the ``shared_utility_qualified_name`` option can be used instead of the ``--shared`` argument. The :file:`setup.py` file would be:
+
+.. code-block:: python
+    :caption: setup.py
+
+    from Cython.Build import cythonize
+    from Cython.Compiler import Options
+    from setuptools import setup, Extension
+
+    Options.shared_utility_qualified_name = 'mypkg.shared._cyutility'

comment_data.body:
This nails the option at import time, regardless of the value at runtime. If users change it after importing Cython, this will fail to produce the intended result.

It's apparently needed across the whole compiler run, from parse to code generation. Thus, it shouldn't be set just here and during parsing. We should change the setting for the whole run of the `SharedModule` pipeline. You can add a pipeline function as reset step after the code generation.

commit.message: Move common functinality to external library
Implement cimporting shared library to compiled file
Generate shared module from real file instad of creating workaround
Remove manual creation of empty tree
When shared utility used dont mark array_cwrapper as used
Fix case when shared utility is used as dependency
inject pxd code after utility code
Fix generating C code for pxd inline functions

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.
